critique: The document is an executive order approving a Code of Fair Competition for Savings, Building and Loan Associations under the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. This act was part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal program, which aimed to address the economic crisis of the Great Depression through government intervention and regulation. The document itself doesn't directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. However, it strongly indicates government intervention in the economy. Given the context of the New Deal, the document leans towards liberal ideology due to its emphasis on government intervention in the economy to address social and economic problems. The approval of the code suggests a centralization of economic control at the federal level.
